Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Bright and Tunable UV Light Emitter from ZnMgO Nanocrystalline System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase (SBIR) II project proposes to develop innovative compositionally tuned nanomaterials based oxide phosphor bright UV light emitting devices that have tunable optical UV light emission. This innovation is based on optical processes emerged in nanomaterials by absorption and emission through band gap engineered meta-stable but high quantum efficiency nanocrystalline, highly directed wires and nanocrystalline epitaxial films. This effort will demonstrate the optimization of nanostructural optical materials with high UV light emission efficiencies and proto-type device integrated with UV lamps.

If successful the outcome of this effort will facilitate applications including invisible UV ink for security applications, medical devices, biological analysis tools, ultraviolet-based secure communications, space sensors, mineral identification, UV curing, UV fluorescent inspection, UV disinfection/sterilization of water, and UV measurement which have market potentials over $500M by 2010. The next generation of UV light sources will enhance UV applications by, 1) Providing additional energy savings, and thus a lower cost of ownership, 2) Enhancing optical spectroscopy, and 3) Enhancing national security applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF SBIR Phase II project developed innovative compositionally tuned bright UV light emitting nanostructures and coatings that have tunable optical UV light emission. This innovation is based on optical processes emerged in nanomaterials by absorption and emission in band gap engineered meta-stable but high quantum efficiency nanocrystalline, highly directed wires and nanocrystalline epitaxial films. Further applications including invisible UV ink for security printing and UV curing. This research also helped in developing nanodeposition tools delivering oxide, nitride, nanodiamond and graphene based nanotechnology materials. Blue Wave also built new partnerships with commercial partners for integrating Blue Wave’s nano processing systems.  We are thus addressing the commercial potential of our nanotechnology products in the field of nano applications. Additionally, activities emerged through this program have also been exploited for commercialization resulting know-how generation, new R&D in carbon electronics, new contracts and new collaborations resulting increase in sales revenue, employee growth and business stability in a highly competing business environment. As a result of the NSF SBIR Phase II grant, Blue Wave significantly gained knowledge in nanotechnology materials synthesis, nanofabrication processes, and application product development some of which are highlighted below:

  • Developed and commercialized integrated physical and chemical deposition system for nanomaterials fabrication. The tool combines multidisciplinary design of the process chamber, precise control of process gas flows, temperatures and pressures  and laser delivery to maintain a controlled environment to achieve the desired deposit of thin film materials and nanostructures.  The integrated process enjoys roles of hot filament generated atomic hydrogen, laser induced plasma, with chemical processes in a single chamber.
  • Developed high quality band gap tunable oxide thin films for thin film capacitors
  • Developed know-how for tool design for formation of single crystal, high quantum efficiency (QE) nanocrystalline highly directed nanowires, epitaxioal films, and nanodiamond coating. Achieved fine control in seeding catalysts, doping, epitaxy, and morphology of electronic and photonic nanomaterials.
  • Blue Wave has also investigated the potential of oxide and nitride based wide band gap nanowires in various commercial fields, such as UV illumination for printing and curing applications.
  • Developed nano-materials based invisible UV emitting ink that can be used for secure messages or security applications. This has immediate uses in the security and defense industries.
